body: Would you like to open a PR to add those to the README?
@manishmalhotrawork, sure, go ahead!

Expected behaviour: `ts > 2019-07-07T23:59:59.9999` can be projected strict using `ts_day` >= 2019-07-08

But for `ts > 2019-07-07T15:46:37.89789`,  `ts_day` >= `2019-07-08` will only return a subset of the records (not returning records between 15th hour and last hour of 2019-07-07), so it cannot be a strict projection based on https://github.com/apache/incubator-iceberg/blob/master/api/src/main/java/org/apache/iceberg/expressions/ResidualEvaluator.java#L203
@rdblue Does this look sane?

Expected behaviour: 
ts > 2019-07-07T23:59:59.9999 can be projected strict using ts_day >= 2019-07-08
ts > 2019-07-07T15:52:50.0000 can also be projected strict using ts_day >= 2019-07-08
After discussing offline, this behaviour is not accurate. Closing.
@rdblue Is it apparent to you what might be the issue here? In `TestFilteredScan.testHourPartitionedTimestampFilters`, it's not returning the expected number of records based on the filter.
cc @rdblue
Thanks for finding and fixing this! I'll merge when tests pass.
Unpartitioned tables use `PartitionSpec.unpartitioned()`.
What does the rule catch when it isn't misbehaving?
@moulimukherjee, did that solve the problem?
+1 LGTM
Merging. Thanks for reviewing, @aokolnychyi!
@rdblue Yes, it did. Thanks!
The rule limits the reference of same literal string up to specific times, which is set to 2 now. String literals like ",", "/", "=" and etc are commonly used and easily hit the rule.
So it should return PartitionSpec.unpartitioned() for specForTables when it found no partition column.
Should `day` also not support the `date` type, since that would be an identity transform?
We should update the spec and the transform to use [`UnicodeUtil`](https://github.com/apache/incubator-iceberg/blob/master/api/src/main/java/org/apache/iceberg/util/UnicodeUtil.java#L42-L54)
Thanks for fixing #292! Do you plan to add more checks for this issue was well?
Is this across files, or just within a single file?
Yes, I will spend some time on this.
You're probably right, although there shouldn't be a difference between the two in practice, once strict projection for dates is added.
I spent some time to try this on spark-shell, and now I 'm converting them to code, @rdblue are you working on this as well? I saw you mentioned in another thread.
From the tip from IntelliJ, it is from a single file.  What 's your preference? Remove it or fix it?
@rdblue updated the PR (forced pushed since the change is minor and not sure if you need to see the difference with previous commit).
Merged. Thanks for contributing this!
Thanks for fixing this, @bryanck!

I think the passing an optional mapping to the conversion from Avro to Iceberg schema makes sense. Let me investigate more on this.

Thanks for the comments!

@edgarRd, sorry for the delay on reviewing this again. I didn't realize it had been updated. If you're waiting on me or another person for reviews, please feel free to use mentions so that I get a notification. I'm also on ASF slack if you want to ping me directly.

I'll take another look at this soon. The last time, I thought it was about ready. The only other concern is that the ORC release with field-level properties is imminent so we might want to wait for that. I'm inclined to merge this and then update to use the new ORC release in a follow-up though.
I haven't yet, feel free to submit a PR!
If you can wait a week, we should have the ORC 1.6 release done. It would be great to hold this until then. ORC 1.6 also gets the timestamp instant type that would be good for iceberg.

@rdblue ptal?
A quick PR https://github.com/apache/incubator-iceberg/pull/303
Just started to get into iceberg. I figured to do a PR for this: https://github.com/apache/incubator-iceberg/pull/304
What are suggested ways to validate backward compatibility?

@rdblue Hey, could you say more about the manual operation here? When you say iceberg should support updateSchema, which class or object are you referring to? Does it have something to do with issue #280 ?

@rdblue @rdsr any chance you could help me with some early review on the current PR?
Looking for input on the effective API for update schema and particular pointers around the implementation so far. Appreciate it.

One question in particular on the implementation side is the approach we should take on the implementation of the visitor pattern for traversing two schemas (DAGs). 
Current approach is that the visitor implements method for handling common fields 
```struct(left, right, fields)```
ownership is implicitly BOTH, never LEFT or RIGHT
and a separate API for visiting left-hand or right-hand only structures
```struct(struct, ownership, fields)``` 
ownership can be LEFT or RIGHT, never BOTH

With this sort of APIs we can decouple the traversal of DAGs from the respective mutation aspects based on differences or commonalities. 
Does this a seem reasonable approach to implementing the visitor pattern for this particular use-case? 

Having an implementation that visits only right hand fields then becomes quite trivial.
I ended up with a bit of a convoluted implementation for the fact that with the current add field API we can't add but to existing fields. 
So in case of us detecting a schema variation such as `a.b.c.d` (nested) fields and we need to add `a` as top-level we need to "hydrate" the entire `NestedField` structure for `a.b.c.d` we can't add recursively in the same commit `a` first, `b` to `a`, `c` to `b` and `d` to `c` respectively.

👋, I'm going through iceberg and it seems quite interesting. I have couple of questions on this issue.

> What do we consider as one batch?

With Spark's Structured Streaming, need to consider the size of a microbatch as well. The size of a microbatch can be defined at the query level. Typically, that would mean reading that number of records from the stream (FileStream) in this case. The [File Source](https://github.com/apache/spark/blob/master/sql/core/src/main/scala/org/apache/spark/sql/execution/streaming/FileStreamSource.scala) in Spark Structured Streaming can read new files per batch. So, the design of a streaming Iceberg File Source can be based on that.

@vrozov Presto does not use any of the metastore code from the Iceberg library. Instead, it uses its existing metastore code from the Hive connector which already has config that fits with Presto, handles Kerberos security, allows alternate metastore implementations such as Glue, etc. The same is true for other Iceberg code including file reading and writing.
@timmylicheng you may need to close and reopen PR to trigger the CI again.

I just noticed that bucketing by float or double is not actually allowed by the specification, nor does the Iceberg library implement. However, the specification mentions how to hash these types, for seemingly no purpose. Would it be better to remove the hash specification to avoid confusion?

FWIW, I agree with the decision to not include bucketing on floating point numbers, since this will almost certainly cause problems and user confusion in practice.

@electrum Problem is not whether presto uses the hive metastore code from the iceberg. Problem is that iceberg uses the hive metastore 1.x API and it is not compatible with hive 3.x API that presto provides at runtime.

@vrozov It doesn’t matter because Presto doesn’t use that code. The classes aren’t referenced at runtime.

BTW, just to clarify, the Presto engine doesn’t provide anything metastore or Hive related at runtime. The Iceberg plugin (like all plugins) is loaded in an isolated class loader and has complete control over all of its dependencies and versions. It is choosing to reuse code and dependencies from the Hive plugin.

@rdblue @danielcweeks what do you think? I am not sure we need this logic in `FastAppend` but it seems reasonable in `MergeAppend`. Alternatively, this can be done by a separate process that will leverage `RewriteManifests`.
@vrozov `HiveClientPool` and related are not used in Presto. You can see the code: https://github.com/prestosql/presto/pull/1067

I'v added a WIP branch with a working POC for vectorization for primitive types in Iceberg 
 https://github.com/prodeezy/incubator-iceberg/tree/issue-9-support-arrow-based-reading-WIP

**Implementation Notes:**
 - Iceberg's Reader adds a `SupportsScanColumnarBatch` mixin to instruct the DataSourceV2ScanExec to use `planBatchPartitions()` instead of the usual `planInputPartitions()`. It returns instances of `ColumnarBatch` on each iteration. 
 - `ArrowSchemaUtil` contains Iceberg to Arrow type conversion. This was copied from [3] . Added by @danielcweeks  . Thanks for that!
 - `VectorizedParquetValueReaders` contains ParquetValueReaders used for reading/decoding the Parquet rowgroups (aka pagestores as referred to in the code) 
 - `VectorizedSparkParquetReaders` contains the visitor implementations to map Parquet types to appropriate value readers. I implemented the struct visitor so that the root schema can be mapped properly. This has the added benefit of vectorization support for structs, so yay!
 - For the initial version the value readers read an entire row group into a single Arrow `FieldVector`. this i'd imagine will require tuning for right batch sizing but i'v gone with one batch per rowgroup for now.
 - Arrow Field Vectors are wrapped using `ArrowColumnVector` which is Spark's `ColumnVector` implementation backed by Arrow. This is the first contact point between Spark and Arrow interfaces. 
 - ArrowColumnVectors are stitched together into a `ColumnarBatch` by `ColumnarBatchReader` . This is my replacement for `InternalRowReader` which maps Structs to Columnar Batches. This allows us to have nested structs where each level of nesting would be a nested columnar batch. Lemme know what you think of this approach. 
 - I'v added value readers for all supported primitive types listed in `AvroDataTest`. There's a corresponding test for vectorized reader under `TestSparkParquetVectorizedReader` 
 - I haven't fixed all the Checkstyle errors so you will have to turn checkstyle off in build.gradle. Also skip tests while building.. sorry! :-(

P.S. There's some unused code under `ArrowReader.java`  Ignore this as it's not used. This was from my previous impl of Vectorization. I'v kept it around to compare performance.

Lemme know what folks think of the approach. I'm getting this working for our scale test benchmark and will report back with numbers. Feel free to run your own benchmarks and share.

> [Presto] uses its existing metastore code from the Hive connector which already has config that fits with Presto, handles Kerberos security, allows alternate metastore implementations such as Glue, etc.

@electrum, how did you add Glue support for Iceberg? Is that something that we should support in this repository so that Spark can read/write tables tracked in Glue? It would be great to be able to reuse what you guys already have done here.

This sounds good to me, but I'm concerned about the number of files that would be required in a single commit to read the target manifest size. How many files are you committing at once? Are those files reasonably sized?

@rdblue The Presto way is likely too complex for the Iceberg library, especially given that it only uses a few metastore calls, but I can share how it works.

Presto has a [HiveMetastore](https://github.com/prestosql/presto/blob/master/presto-hive/src/main/java/io/prestosql/plugin/hive/metastore/HiveMetastore.java) interface that uses its own model objects such as [Table](https://github.com/prestosql/presto/blob/master/presto-hive/src/main/java/io/prestosql/plugin/hive/metastore/Table.java). Glue implements the interface directly as [GlueMetastore](https://github.com/prestosql/presto/blob/master/presto-hive/src/main/java/io/prestosql/plugin/hive/metastore/glue/GlueHiveMetastore.java) using the AWS SDK for Java.

Presto also has a [ThriftMetastore](https://github.com/prestosql/presto/blob/master/presto-hive/src/main/java/io/prestosql/plugin/hive/metastore/thrift/ThriftMetastore.java) interface that uses the generated libthrift classes such as `org.apache.hadoop.hive.metastore.api.Table` from the Apache Hive dependency (except for table and column statistics classes which don't exist in Hive). The implementation [ThriftHiveMetastore](https://github.com/prestosql/presto/blob/master/presto-hive/src/main/java/io/prestosql/plugin/hive/metastore/thrift/ThriftHiveMetastore.java) handles retry and JMX statistics collection, maps Thrift exceptions into Presto exceptions, and some other basic mapping including `null` to `Optional`.

Thrift implements `HiveMetastore` using [BridgingHiveMetastore](https://github.com/prestosql/presto/blob/master/presto-hive/src/main/java/io/prestosql/plugin/hive/metastore/thrift/BridgingHiveMetastore.java) which translates to the `ThriftMetastore` interface and converts the model objects using [ThriftMetastoreUtil](https://github.com/prestosql/presto/blob/master/presto-hive/src/main/java/io/prestosql/plugin/hive/metastore/thrift/ThriftMetastoreUtil.java).

Iceberg needs a smaller number of methods, but the complexity comes from the model objects. Doing a generic conversion from `org.apache.hadoop.hive.metastore.api.Table` to  `com.amazonaws.services.glue.model.Table` seems feasible, since the structures are very similar, but much of the code would go unused (e.g., Iceberg doesn't use Hive partitioning or bucketing). It might be cleaner to duplicate the logic at a higher level using the AWS Glue client directly.

I saw one table with a wrong partitioning that caused a commit of ± 2 million files and ±500 MB manifest size. Of course, that was a configuration error.

Manifest size can be around 8MB if you commit ±10000 files. Let's actually keep this open and not address it now. Even if we write a couple of TB in one batch, it shouldn't be a big problem to have a slightly bigger manifest. Might not be worth the complexity.
Recently, some unit tests fail randomly. Close and reopen to trigger CI again. We need to fix that.

@electrum The PR has 46 files added/modified, and the only relevant to the discussion in this thread class is `io.prestosql.iceberg.HiveTableOperations`, so it was quite easy to miss that file. Anyway, would not it be better to change iceberg `org.apache.iceberg.hive.HiveTableOperations` to allow Presto/Drill/Spark to provide it's own Hive metastore client, instead of re-implementing that class in Presto, especially that `BaseMetastoreTableOperations` that `HiveTableOperations` extends is not part of the iceberg api library?

There is a short description in spec.md on this "2. Float hash values are the result of hashing the float cast to double to ensure that schema evolution does not change hash values if float types are promoted. Note that floating point types are not valid source values for partitioning."

But I agree with you. Having the comments saying bucketing by float or double is not allowed, the actual implementation seems useless.

How about I remove the description in spec.md as well as BucketFloat and BucketDouble class?

@rdblue Thoughts? Saw your initial commit.
@rdblue Now every manifest only has one partitionSpecId. Do this mean if a table had multiple partition specs, there would be multiple manifest for it?

@electrum, thanks for the explanation. How do you implement the table lock operation for Glue? Is that supported directly in the AWS SDK? If so, we should probably add an iceberg-glue module to support it from Spark.
Yes. If a table has multiple partition specs, it will probably have multiple manifests, each written with one of those specs.
I agree. There may be use cases that require this, but we don't usually expect this to happen without a configuration problem like your case.
Thanks for fixing this!

I forgot that I had already thought about bucketing with floating point numbers and decided it was a bad idea. I'm glad you guys caught that in the spec (and that we wrote it down!).

The reason to define a hash function for floating point numbers is that we may need it for other uses, and we need to be careful with hashing and schema evolution.

The hash spec produces the same result for a value in all types the value may later be promoted to. That's why `h(1) == h(1L)`. That is required for bucketing to work when a bucketed column is promoted from `int` to `long`. While we don't support bucketing on floating point values, I think this property should be preserved if we ever do use the hash spec with floating point values.
Thanks for fixing this, @dchristle! Merged.
Can you update the description with what this changes and why it is useful?

> Of course, having a way to roll back the entire table state and minimizing changes to the Catalog API are reasonable benefits. The drawback is that we will have to create a separate instance of HiveTableOperations with its own HMS client pool.

Why is this? Wouldn't the table use the client pool from the Catalog instance? I think `TableOperations` is exposed from `BaseTable`, right? So as long as you are using the `HiveCatalog`, you'd get a table with an accessible operations object.

To avoid the issue of a table being available before the metadata is replaced, we should add the create/replace transaction methods to `Catalog`. We'll need those for atomic operations anyway.
@rdblue updated the description.
@edgarRd, sorry about not following up sooner, I was unexpectedly out of the office for the last few days. Since the ORC release is almost out, let's wait for it. Thanks!

@rdsr, I've been working on #41, and I think we may have some restructuring to the mapping, instead of a simple name to ID map. Supporting aliases with a simple map requires enumerating all of the possibilities, and it is difficult to work with. I think a multi-level approach, where each struct has a mapping is going to be better to work with. I'll clean up what I have and post a PR for you to look at.
Thanks @rdblue !
@arina-ielchiieva, why is this needed? Shouldn't the mode always be overwrite?

@rdblue 
whether to overwrite file or fail when file already exists depends on application strategy:
1. if you are confident that you always create unique files and then somehow collision has occurred, you would prefer to know that something went wrong rather than implicitly overwriting the file.
2. on the other hand, when creating a several files: some files were created successfully, some were not, and you have retry strategy that attempts to create the same files one more time, in this case overwrite mode maybe more preferable.
In my opinion, having options is more flexible than adjusting to some default behavior that's why I have made write modes configurable. If you think this is overhead, we can always chose one default behavior for these readers since unfortunately currently they behave differently.

A few of us met with @prodeezy to discuss the poc implementation (great work btw) and look at the future work we all hope to be contributing to.  I've captured some of the discussion and ideas of where we going and considerations here: https://docs.google.com/document/d/1qVcowrYP6xBoB9C4htwEA0QvbHpdstzieNsX26SMG2k/edit#heading=h.yun6jblu7cfi

Feel free to add comments.  I think with a little cleanup we might be close to having an initial implementation that we can start iterating on.  @rdblue had proposed creating a branch, which I'm all for so we can work more openly and get more eyes on the implementation.

(@samarthjain @anjalinorwood)
@rdblue thanks for the follow up. Sounds good, I'll keep an eye on the ORC release. Thanks!

@rdblue Getcha.
@electrum Shall I leave the codes there and just update the spec.md with wording like "float(double) is not supported. Be careful."?
PR #303 is merged btw. @electrum
@timmylicheng thanks!
I'd prefer to remove it from the specification (maybe just comment it out in the specification source for easy restoration) to avoid confusion, but that's @rdblue's call.
@rdblue So that for every current() TableMetadata, the spec() should return the one with the last assigned ID instead of the defaultSpecId?

@timmylicheng, sorry for the confusion. The partition spec ID and the IDs I'm talking about here aren't the same thing. Partition specs are assigned IDs so that we can write manifest files that reference those specs, I think you're talking about those IDs.

The IDs I'm talking about here are schema field IDs that are used to write the record of partition data in the manifest file. Right now, those IDs are assigned each time a manifest file is created, starting at 1000. Instead, we should use persistent IDs for each unique partition field and keep track of the last assigned ID for partition evolution.
Clicking through to the Travis UI shows that the tests succeeded. I'm not sure why Github wasn't updated.
I think we should make a decision and have a single default behavior instead of adding table properties. I don't see much value in being able to configure this differently across tables.
@rdblue ptal again?

@rdblue Ah no worries. I'm using this issue to get familiar with the code case :P.
Thanks for patience to guide thru. I'm looking around for the schema field ID you refer to. At the same time, it would be awesome if you could point me at the class or the member.

@rdblue please review.

Hey @prodeezy, thanks for updating and creating the pull request.  Looks like the build is breaking and while we don't need exhaustive reviews, it would be nice to keep the branch in a buildable state.  I pulled it down and it looks like the dependency locks are preventing.  Could you just add the updated version locks to pull in arrow (i.e. `gradlew --write-locks`)?

There are a number of checkstyle violations, but I think we can look past those for now (unless you want to tackle them with the version locks).

will do. i have a different branch "vectorized-read" in my local repo with latest code from master merged in. will update locks and fix checkstyle errors and create another pr. closing this for now. sorry bout the confusion.
What about adding a note that points out that the hash function is defined, but bucketing by floating point values is not allowed?
raised https://github.com/apache/incubator-iceberg/pull/319 as a replacement with the updated version locks and checkstyle errors fixed.
tests fail but check-style checks pass.
Merged. Thanks for working on this, @moulimukherjee!
@prodeezy I'm going to go ahead and commit this now, which will hopefully unblock others to start making pull requests.
This should be helpful for testing the latest changes easily in downstream projects. Thanks for fixing it!
Will be using https://github.com/apache/incubator-iceberg/tree/vectorized-read going forward to iterate on this feature.
